factoid: Napoleon was offended at the demand that he withdraw beyond the Vistula.
Napoleon ordered his troops to advance.
If Napoleon had not taken offense at the demand to withdraw beyond the Vistula and had not ordered his troops to advance, there would have been no war.
If all of Napoleon's sergeants had objected to serving a second term, there could have been no war.
If there had been no English intrigues, there would have been no war.
If there had been no Duke of Oldenburg, there would have been no war.
If Tsar Alexander I had not felt insulted, there would have been no war.
If Russia had not had an autocratic government, there would have been no war.
If France had not had a Revolution, there would have been no war.
If France had not had a subsequent dictatorship and Empire, there would have been no war.
If France had not had all the causes that produced the French Revolution, there would have been no war.
Without each of these causes nothing could have happened.
All of these causes coincided to bring about the war.
There was no single cause for the war, but it had to occur because it had to.
Millions of men renounced their human feelings and reason and had to march from west to east to slay their fellow soldiers.
Centuries earlier hordes of men had come from the east to the west, slaying their fellow soldiers.
The actions of Napoleon and Tsar Alexander I were as little voluntary as the actions of any soldier drawn into the campaign by lot or conscription.
The will of Napoleon and Tsar Alexander I should be carried out by the concurrence of innumerable circumstances.
Millions of soldiers who fired weapons or transported provisions and guns consented to carry out the will of Napoleon and Tsar Alexander I.
Millions of soldiers were induced to do so by an infinite number of diverse and complex causes.
We are forced to fall back on fatalism as an explanation of irrational events.
The more we try to explain such events in history reasonably, the more unreasonable and incomprehensible they become to us.
Each man lives for himself, using his freedom to attain his personal aims, and feels that he can now do or abstain from doing this or that action.
As soon as a man has acted, that action performed at a certain moment becomes irrevocable and belongs to history, in which it has a predestined significance.
Every man has two sides to his life: his individual life, which is more free the more abstract its interests, and his elemental hive life, in which he inevitably obeys laws laid down for him.
A man lives consciously for himself, but is an unconscious instrument in the attainment of the historic, universal aims of humanity.
A deed done is irrevocable, and its result coinciding in time with the actions of millions of other men assumes a historic significance.
The higher a man stands on the social ladder, the more people he is connected with and the more power he has over others, the more evident is the predestination and inevitability of his every action.
The king’s heart is in the hands of the Lord.
A king is history’s slave.
History uses every moment of the life of kings as a tool for its own purposes.
Napoleon in 1812 was more convinced than ever that the war depended on him.
Napoleon was in the grip of inevitable laws, which compelled him, while thinking that he was acting on his own volition, to perform for the hive life whatever had to be performed.
Napoleon expressed that he would shed the blood of his peoples.
